commander.name: Generale di Divisione Francesco Antonelli
commander.previous_service: Commander from 1939 until capture at Bardia, January 1941

supply_logistics.supply_status: Poor. CC.NN. divisions received lowest priority for supplies compared to regular Army divisions. Division surrounded at Bardia from 1 December 1940, isolated from main supply lines. Water shortage critical in static defensive positions.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal defensive positions, fortified perimeter at Bardia
weather_environment.environmental_challenges: Static defensive positions in rocky terrain. Limited water sources in Bardia perimeter. Exposed coastal positions subject to naval bombardment. December siege conditions with diminishing supplies.
weather_environment.seasonal_impacts: Cooler temperatures reduced water requirements compared to summer but created challenges for troops in minimal shelter. Occasional winter rains improved water availability but degraded defensive positions.

subordinate_units.notes: Formed by depot of 9th Army Corps Artillery Regiment in Foggia. I Gruppo: 12x 75/27, II Gruppo: 12x 75/27, III Gruppo: 12x 100/17, 2x AA batteries: 8x 20/65, 2x support batteries (219th & 233rd): 8x 65/17
8x 47/32 AT guns organized in gun platoons

tactical_doctrine.role: Static defense of Bardia fortress perimeter. CC.NN. divisions were primarily organized for internal security and occupation duties. Division held the central 'Ponticelli' sector of Bardia defenses alongside elements of 62nd Infantry Division 'Marmarica'.
known_issues: Lower combat effectiveness compared to regular Army divisions
Weak anti-tank capability against British Matilda tanks
Poor coordination with regular Army units
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Minimal. CC.NN. divisions lacked specialized desert equipment and training. Static defensive positions at Bardia provided some protection but limited tactical flexibility.

special_rules: Vulnerable to armor attacks (weak AT capability)
British testimony: 'fought well and inflicted considerable casualties'
historical_engagements: Destroyed at Battle of Bardia (3-5 January 1941)

source: TM-E 30-420 'Handbook on the Italian Military Forces' (US War Department, 3 August 1943) - Paragraphs 13-14: MVSN organization, command structure, legion formations, estimated strength 340,000 personnel

Lucas, Ettore and de Vecchi, Giorgio. 'Storia delle Unità Combattenti della MVSN 1923-1943' (Giovanni Volpe Editore, 1976), pages 63-116 - Primary Italian source on CCNN combat units, organizational tables, equipment allocations
Madej, W. Victor. 'Italian Army Order of Battle: 1940-1944' (Valor Publishing, 1990, 2nd ed.) - CCNN division organization, unit histories including capture locations, Fascist Militia unit structures
Madej, W. Victor. 'Italian Army Handbook 1940-1944' (Valor Publishing) - Equipment tables, tactical doctrine, combat performance assessments
Nafziger, George F. 'Italian Order of Battle World War II' (3 volumes, 1996) - Detailed organizational structures, CCNN divisions absorbed from 21 Aprile Division May 1940
Greene, Jack and Massignani, Alessandro. 'Rommel's North African Campaign' - Combat performance of CCNN divisions Libya 1940-1941, tactical assessments

Wargaming.info - 'Camicie Nere: The Blackshirts (MVSN & CCNN Combat Units)' - Division structure: 2 legions (each 3 battalions), 1 MG battalion (3 companies, 16 HMG each), 1 AT company (4 platoons 47/32), 1 artillery regiment, 1 engineer battalion, 1 light tank battalion (L3/35). Combat assessment: 'lack of heavy weapons and poor command and tactics'
Axis History Forum - '1. Blackshirt Division 23 Marzo (Italy)' - Raised 1939, sent Libya summer 1940, destroyed Bardia January 1941, named for Fascist Party founding 23 March 1919
Seed unit file (north_africa_seed_units_COMPLETE.json) - Combat participation confirmed for 1940-Q4 (invasion Egypt, Sidi Barrani, withdrawal to Bardia) and 1941-Q1 (Battle of Bardia 3-5 January)

artillery_counts.reason: 201st Artillery Regiment composition verified from multiple authoritative sources. Specific breakdown: I Gruppo (12x 75/27), II Gruppo (12x 75/27), III Gruppo (12x 100/17), plus AA and support batteries. Standard CCNN divisional artillery allocation.
sources_checked: TM-E 30-420 'Handbook on the Italian Military Forces' (US War Department, 1943) - MVSN artillery allocations
Madej, W. Victor. 'Italian Army Order of Battle: 1940-1944' - CCNN division artillery structures
Lucas & de Vecchi. 'Storia delle Unità Combattenti della MVSN 1923-1943' (1976) - Primary Italian artillery tables
Wargaming.info - CCNN division equipment tables confirming 65/17, 75/27, 100/17 allocations
artillery_counts.verification_method: Cross-referenced artillery composition from US military intelligence (TM-E 30-420), primary Italian sources (Lucas & de Vecchi 1976), and secondary military historians (Madej). All confirm standard CCNN pattern: two field gun gruppos (75mm), one howitzer gruppo (100/17mm), AA batteries (20mm), support weapon batteries (65/17mm).

subordinate_commanders.reason: Legion and battalion commanders not documented in available sources. Division commander (Gen. Div. Francesco Antonelli) confirmed from multiple sources.
sources_checked: TM-E 30-420 'Handbook on the Italian Military Forces' (1943) - No subordinate CCNN commanders listed
Madej, W. Victor. 'Italian Army Order of Battle: 1940-1944' - Division-level commanders only
Lucas & de Vecchi. 'Storia delle Unità Combattenti della MVSN 1923-1943' (1976) - Focus on unit histories, not personnel
Axis History Forum - Commander names not provided for subordinate units
subordinate_commanders.mitigation: Subordinate commanders typically not critical for division-level wargaming scenarios. Check Ufficio Storico Stato Maggiore dell'Esercito (Italian Army Historical Office) archives if needed for future research.
